Graphical abstract The present work deals with the analysis of a series of cobalt catalysts (20 and 30%wt.Co) supported on alumina modified with MgO (7–18%wt.Mg with respect to the support) for the combustion of dilute methane. Both modified supports and the resulting cobalt catalysts were characterised by N2 physisorption, wavelength dispersive X-ray fluorescence, X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy and temperature-programmed reduction with hydrogen. A beneficial effect on catalytic activity was found with respect to the reference samples supported on blank alumina. As evidenced by the kinetic results in terms of specific reaction rate and apparent activation energy, this positive influence was related to a partial inhibition generation of less active CoAl2O4 due to MgO coverage of the support in favour of increasing the amount of easily reducible cobalt species, mainly in the form of Co3O4. The optimum magnesium loading was 12%wt. irrespective of the cobalt content, while the catalysts with 30%wt.Co were significantly more active than their counterparts with 20%wt.Co. Finally, a good catalytic stability with time on stream (150 h) was observed. Keywords Methane oxidation Cobalt oxide Alumina supported catalysts Magnesium oxide 1 Introduction Methane is a powerful greenhouse effect gas with a global warming potential of around 28 for a 100-year period, and it accounts for around 20% of the total radiative forcing from all greenhouse gases [1,2] From all the anthropogenic sources, energy production and transport seem to be the two sectors that produce the most emissions of methane. Facilities such as oil refineries or natural gas plants and natural gas engines usually release low concentrations of methane that are difficult to remove due to the high stability of this molecule [3,4]. Since these off-gases are generally characterised by large flows at low to moderate temperatures, catalytic oxidation is the preferred abatement technique. Traditionally, catalysts for this application are based on noble metals such as palladium and platinum. However, nowadays there is an increasing interest on substituting these materials by cheaper systems, namely transition metal oxides with a defined structure such as spinels, perovskites or hexaaluminates, which can be equally active and stable [5–7]. Spinel oxides, and in particular, spinel-type cobalt oxide (Co3O4) is a widely known material that can serve as an alternative to noble metals for catalytic oxidation due to its good redox properties [8–11]. However, its generally poor structural and textural properties tend to hinder the potential activity of this material, especially when it is prepared by conventional synthesis methodologies [12,13]. One possible solution to this problem could be to support the cobalt oxide over the surface of a porous media, in order to increase the amount of surface area available for the reaction. Although this option generally enhances the structural properties of the catalyst, it also presents a major drawback related to the fact that the cobalt-support interaction almost invariably has a detrimental effect on the redox properties of supported Co3O4, thus balancing out the benefits of improved structural properties [14,15]. Specifically when the chosen support is alumina, the cobalt-support interaction also leads to the formation of an inactive cobalt aluminate phase (CoAl2O4) characterised by a poor reducibility [16,17]. A proposed solution already found in the bibliography has been the modification of the support with the purpose of altering its stability and affinity for the cobalt oxide supported over it. This can be addressed by adding some chemical promoters to the alumina support before the incorporation of Co3O4, or by adding these promoters to the final Co/Al2O3 catalyst. In this sense, Cheng at al. [18] found that Cu-Co mixed oxide catalysts supported over modified alumina obtained by a co-precipitation method were highly active for methane oxidation, especially when the alumina was modified with manganese. On the other hand, El-Shobaky et al. [19] reported an increased activity of Co3O4/Al2O3 catalysts for CO oxidation when these were doped with small amounts of manganese and/or lanthanum. Alternatively, using magnesium as a modifier for this type of catalysts seems to be a good way to improve their performance. For instance, Riad [20] found that magnesium-modified alumina prepared by co-precipitation exhibited better textural and structural properties than bare alumina. Magnesium oxide can be also used as a support for cobalt catalysts as well, thereby resulting in systems with an improved activity owing to the magnesium-cobalt interaction as reported by Ulla et al. [14] and Ji et al. [21] In this context, the present investigation is based on our previous results on the comparison of bulk and supported Co3O4 catalysts, and more particularly, on the effect of Co loading (10–40%wt.Co) for the combustion of methane on Co3O4/Al2O3 catalysts [22,23]. Thus, the best results were found for the 20–30%wt. loadings. This work aims at designing improved supported catalysts by means of surface protection of the alumina support before incorporation of the Co3O4 phase. To the best of our knowledge, there are no research studies in the available literature regarding the use of this type of catalysts for this environmental application. On the basis of the fact that the deposited MgO should act as a physical barrier between deposited cobalt and the alumina support, thereby limiting the cobalt-alumina interaction and the subsequent cobalt aluminate formation, the objective will be to study the catalytic behaviour of a set of cobalt catalysts with varying metallic loading (20 and 30%wt.) supported on three different modified-alumina supports (7–18%wt.Mg) for the oxidation of trace amounts of methane. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation The magnesium-modified alumina supports were prepared by precipitation of a magnesium precursor on a commercial γ-alumina (Saint-Gobain), which was previously thermally stabilised at 850 °C for 4 h in static air. For each support, 5 g of γ-alumina were mixed with 100 ml of magnesium (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, Merck) with adjusted concentrations of Mg. Then, a solution of Na2CO3 1.2 M was added drop-by-drop while the temperature of the mixture was kept at 80 °C, until the pH was 8.5. The selected magnesium loadings were 7, 12 and 18%wt.Mg. The obtained precipitates were collected and washed with at least 5 litres of water to eliminate all the residual sodium ions from the precursor. These supports were denoted as xMg-Al2O3 where x stands for the measured magnesium loading. On the other hand, a support of pure magnesia (MgO) was also prepared by applying the same precipitation route using a magnesium nitrate solution. Supported Co/Mg-Al2O3, Co/Al2O3 and Co/MgO catalysts were prepared following the same precipitation route as the supports but starting with a mixture of 5 g of each support in powder form and 100 ml of cobalt (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, Alfa Aesar) with adjusted concentrations of Co. The chosen Co loadings were 20 and 30%wt. These samples were denoted as yCo/xMg-Al2O3 where y stands for the cobalt loading. All supports and catalyst precursors were dried in static air at 110 °C for 16 h and then subjected to calcination in static air to produce the final supports and catalysts. The calcination protocol involved three heating ramps separated with two 30-min isotherms: an initial ramp from ambient temperature up to 125 °C at 5 °C min−1, an intermediate ramp from 125 to 300 °C at 1 °C min−1 and a final ramp at 5 °C min−1 up to 600 °C, which was the maintained for 4 h. In this way, the xMg-Al2O3 supports were calcined at 600 °C for 4 h in order to obtain the MgO phase. Then, the Co catalysts were submitted to an additional activation thermal step at 600 °C for 4 h in static air so as to induce the formation of Co3O4. Exceptionally, one of the Mg-modified alumina supports (18Mg-Al2O3) was also calcined at 850 °C for 4 h. The selection of this specific thermal programme was made on the basis of the thermogravimetric analysis of the oxidative decomposition of the precipitated cobalt precursor, namely cobalt hydroxide carbonate, into Co3O4. Hence, it was observed that this transformation occurred in the 125–300 °C temperature range (Fig. S1, Supplementary material). A number of reference samples were also prepared since they could be useful for the interpretation of the characterisation results of the various Mg-Al2O3 supports and the examined Co/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts. These materials were bulk Co3O4, CoAl2O4 and MgAl2O4. Bulk Co3O4 was prepared following the same precipitation route detailed above, starting from a solution of cobalt nitrate (II) hexahydrate. On the other hand, bulk CoAl2O4 and MgAl2O4 were prepared by co-precipitation routes via layered double hydroxide precursors [24,25]. 2.2 Characterisation techniques Textural properties of the samples were determined from the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms at −196 °C obtained with a Micromeritics TriStar II apparatus. The specific surface of the samples was obtained by the BET method, and the average pore size was calculated using the BJH method. All samples were degassed prior to analysis on a Micromeritics SmartPrep apparatus at 300 °C for 10 h with a N2 flow. The composition of the supports and catalysts was determined by Wavelength Dispersive X-Ray Fluorescence (WDXRF). From each sample in powder form, a boron glass pearl was prepared by fusion in an induction micro-furnace, by mixing the sample with the flux agent Spectromelt A12 (Merck) in an approximate proportion of 20:1. Chemical analysis of each pearl was performed under vacuum, using a PANalytical AXIOS sequential WDXRF spectrometer, equipped with a Rh tube and three different detectors (gas flow, scintillation and Xe sealed). Structural properties of the catalysts were determined by X-Ray diffraction. XRD analysis were performed on a X’PERT-PRO X-Ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.5406 Å) and a Ni filter. The X-Ray tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA of current. The samples were scanned from an initial value of 2θ = 5° to a final value of 2θ = 80°, with a step size of 0.026° and a counting time of 2.0 s. Phase identification was performed by comparison of the obtained diffraction patterns with JCPDS (Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards) database cards. The analysis by Raman spectroscopy was carried out by using a Renishaw InVia Raman spectrometer, coupled to a Leica DMLM microscope. The excitation wavelength was 514 nm (ion-argon laser, Modu-Laser). The spatial resolution was 2 microns. For each spectrum, 20 s were employed and five scans were accumulated with the 10% of the maximum power of the 514 nm laser in a spectral window of 150–1500 cm−1. Finally, temperature-programmed reduction with hydrogen (H2-TPR) was performed on a Micromeritics Autochem 2920 apparatus, using a 5%H2/Ar mixture as the reducing gas. The analysis protocol involved an initial pre-treatment step with a 5%O2/He mixture at 300 °C for 30 min. After cooling down to room temperature with flowing He, the TPR experiment was performed, up to 950 °C for all the samples. This final temperature was then maintained for 30 min. The water produced throughout the whole experiment was eliminated using a cold trap, to avoid interference with the TCD detector. 2.3 Catalytic activity determination Catalytic activity tests were performed at atmospheric pressure in a bench-scale fixed bed reactor (PID Eng&Tech S.L.) in the 300–600 °C temperature range. Each reaction experiment was made by using 1 g of catalyst (particle size of 0.25–0.3 mm) diluted with the same mass of inert quartz (particle size 0.5–0.8 mm) to enhance heat and reactants distribution along the catalytic bed. The calcined samples were not submitted to any further activation treatment prior to the catalytic runs. The feedstream (1%CH4, 10%O2 and N2 as the balance gas) was fed to the reactor with a total flow of 500 cm3 min−1, which corresponded to a space velocity of 300 ml CH4 g−1 h−1 (60,000 h−1 approximately for an estimated catalyst density of 2 g cm-3). Conversion measurements and product profiles were taken at steady state each 25 °C, typically after 15 min on stream. The furnace temperature was programmed in a stepwise progression. Each temperature level was attained using a heating ramp of 1 °C min−1. Each chromatographic analysis was performed in triplicate in order to check reproducibility, and it was found that the standard deviation for every set of three values was always below 1%. Additionally, stability tests were carried out for a total time on stream of 150 h at 500 °C. Further details on the experimental set-up and the analysis of the product stream are detailed elsewhere [22]. The absence of diffusional limitations that could affect the obtained catalytic results was checked in agreement to the Eurokin procedure (see Table S1, Supplementary material). Hence, according to the obtained results for intragranular and extra-granular mass diffusion, energy diffusion and temperature gradients, it was considered that the catalytic activity results were not significantly influenced by interphase transportation phenomena. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterisation of Mg-Al2O3 modified supports The physico-chemical properties of the as-prepared MgO-modified alumina supports were investigated by WDXRF, XRD and N2 physisorption. The Mg loading as determined by WDXRF varied between 7 and 18%wt. (Table 1 ). The X-ray diffractograms of the supports are shown in Fig. 1 . As a reference the pattern of pure MgO is included as well. Expectedly all the samples displayed signals attributable to a cubic phase of gamma-alumina (2θ = 32.0, 37.7, 45.6 and 67.3°, JCPDS 01-074-2206). The samples with a Mg content of 12 and 18%wt. also showed distinct signals assignable to a cubic phase of magnesium oxide (JCPDS 00-004-0829) at 2θ = 43.0, 62.3, 74.7 and 78.6°. Note that the signal at 2θ = 37.0° could be ascribed to both Al2O3 and MgO phases. From the XRD peak intensity of the signals of MgO (2θ = 62.3°) and γ-alumina (2θ = 67.3°), which varied from 0.07 for the 7 Mg/Al2O3 sample to 0.84 for the 18 Mg/Al2O3 sample, it was verified that the relative amount of crystalline MgO increased with Mg loading. The MgO crystallite size was estimated from the full width half maximum of the characteristic peak located at 2θ = 42.9°, which corresponded to the (2 0 0) plane, by applying the Scherrer equation. Irrespective of the Mg content, the crystallite size was around 10–11 nm, which was half of that of pure magnesia (21 nm), thus evidencing a good dispersion of MgO over the surface of the alumina. On the other hand, the absence of segregated MgO in the pattern of the 7 MgO-Al2O3 support was coherent with the proximity of its Mg loading to that theoretically required to form a MgO monolayer (about 10%wt.) [26]. On the other hand, the possible formation of MgAl2O4 due to the interaction between MgO and Al2O3 could be ruled out as the main signals of this spinel (2θ = 31.3, 36.9, 44.8, 59.4 and 65.2°, JCPDS 00-005-0672) were not observed. This was reasonably expected since the calcination temperature of the investigated Mg/Al2O3 samples was 600 °C while the formation of the spinel is reported to occur above this temperature [27]. In this sense, the pattern of the 18Mg-Al2O3 calcined at 850 °C (18Mg-Al2O3-850), on which the formation of MgAl2O4 was induced, is included in Fig. 1 for the sake of comparison. The textural properties of the supports in terms of BET surface area, mean pore diameter and pore volume are listed in Table 1. In addition, the results corresponding to the pure MgO sample synthesised by precipitation are also included. The following values were obtained for the blank alumina support 136 m2 g−1, 0.55 cm3 g−1 and 123 Å. After MgO deposition, the surface area slightly increased up to 139–145 m2 g−1, probably due to the contribution of its intrinsic porosity to the resultant support. In this sense, the pore size distributions of the supports (Fig. S2, Supplementary material) evidenced the appearance of a fraction of small mesopores (with sizes around 30–40 Å) attributable to the high dispersion of magnesia, which in turn also exhibited a pore size distribution centred around that pore size range. A similar increase in surface area was found by Caloch et al. when studying MgO-Al2O3 supports prepared by homogeneous precipitation. This was assigned to the interaction of magnesium and aluminium oxides creating new narrow mesopores that contributed to the total surface area [28]. On the contrary, both pore volume and mean pore size were much more affected with a marked decrease from 0.55 to 0.44 cm3 g−1 and 123 to 110 Å, respectively. 3.2 Characterisation of Co/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts A set of Co/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts was prepared by precipitation with two Co loadings, namely 20 and 30%wt. For comparative purposes, four reference cobalt catalysts supported on bare alumina and magnesia (20Co/Al2O3, 20Co/MgO, 30Co/Al2O3 and 30Co/MgO) were also examined. Table 1 includes the composition of the synthesised catalysts as determined by WDXRF. It must be pointed out that the actual Mg loading of the Co/Mg-Al2O3 samples (3–11%wt.) was appreciably lower than that theoretically expected (5–14%wt.) due to a partial leaching of the promoter during the cobalt deposition step. This was verified by the significant presence of Mg in the filtrates after Co precipitation as evidenced by ICP-AES analysis. Figs. 2 and 3 show the diffractograms of the cobalt catalysts. These patterns were characterised by the presence of γ-alumina (2θ = 67.3°) and a spinel-like cobalt phase (Co3O4 and/or CoAl2O4), (2θ = 31.3, 37.0, 45.1, 59.4 and 65.3°, JCPDS 00-042-1467 and JCPDS 00-044-0160). Note that it was not possible to differentiate between these two oxides since both phase crystallise in the cubic structure. The MgO phase was only detected (2θ = 43.0 and 62.3°) over the catalysts with the highest content of magnesium, namely 20Co/18Mg-Al2O3 and 30Co/18Mg-Al2O3. Furthermore, a close-up view of the diffraction signals of the Co spinel phase in the patterns of the catalysts with a 20%wt.Co revealed a significant position shift with increasing Mg loading. This shift was noticed for all the signals attributed to this phase. For the sake of clarity only the signal located at around 2θ = 37.0° is shown in Fig. 4 . This signal was noted at 2θ = 37.1° for the catalyst supported on bare alumina (20Co/Al2O3) and progressively shifted towards 2θ = 36.9°, being this diffraction angle virtually coincident with that observed when cobalt was supported on pure magnesia (20Co/MgO). This finding suggested that the Co3O4 phase switched from a Co-alumina-type interaction (which resulted in the formation of CoAl2O4) to a Co-magnesia-type interaction (which eventually involved a less favoured formation of CoAl2O4) with increasing Mg loadings. This shift was also indicative of an enlargement of the unit cell of the associated Co spinel phase, which was in agreement with some extent of lattice distortion of the cobalt spinel phase (enlargement of the unit cell size from 8.039 Å to 8.069 Å) due to the interaction with magnesia [29]. Moreover, a progressive widening of these signals was observed, thereby suggesting some inhibition of the crystallisation of the Co-phase [30]. The addition of increasing amounts of cobalt oxide led to an appreciable negative impact on the textural properties of the resultant catalyst (Table 1). Hence, when compared with the corresponding MgO-modified alumina support, the BET surface area decreased by 16–20% for the 20Co/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts and about 32% for the 30Co/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts. The same trend was observed for the mean pore size (29–38% for the 20Co/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts and 36–46% for the 30Co/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts). These results clearly indicated that the cobalt species deposited over the surface of the support gradually blocked its largest pores with increasing metallic loading. On the other hand, when compared with the reference bare alumina-supported cobalt catalysts (Table 1), no large differences were noticed for the 20Co/Mg-Al2O3 samples (113–118 m2 g−1 versus 120 m2 g−1 over 20Co/Al2O3). For the catalysts with a larger Co content, a more noticeable decrease impact was visible (91–99 m2 g−1 versus 108 m2 g−1 over 30Co/Al2O3). The Raman spectra of the Co/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 (20Co/Mg-Al2O3) and 6 (30Co/Mg-Al2O3). For the sake of comparison, the spectra of the Co/Al2O3 and Co/MgO counterpart catalysts and the bulk Co3O4 and CoAl2O4 samples are also included. All the supported catalysts displayed the five Raman actives modes associated with Co3O4, namely three F2g modes located at 194, 519 and 617 cm−1, and the Eg and A1g modes at 479 cm−1 and 687 cm−1, respectively [31]. However, the Mg-containing catalysts showed comparatively weaker and wider signals. In line with the XRD results, this feature suggested a lattice distortion of the Co3O4 phase in these samples due to its interaction with magnesium. On the other hand, a close-up view of the A1g vibration mode (650–725 cm−1) for the 20Co/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts clearly evidenced the presence of additional shoulders attached to this peak at 705 and 725 cm−1 in the 20Co/Al2O3 sample (Fig. 7). These signals (denoted as A1g*) were also visible for the bulk CoAl2O4 sample and are usually attributed to some inversion degree in the structure of cobalt aluminate [32,33]. The absence of these signals for the Co/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts pointed out that these samples contained lower amounts of CoAl2O4, owing to a lesser extent of the cobalt-alumina interaction. In addition to that, the A1g signal of the Mg-containing catalysts displayed an initial bathochromic shift (7 cm−1) with increasing magnesium loadings up to 5%wt. (20Co/12Mg-Al2O3) that could be attributed to a change in the predominant cobalt-support interaction, from cobalt-alumina to cobalt-magnesia [14]. For higher magnesium loadings (11%wt.Mg, 20Co/18Mg-Al2O3), the signal returned to a very similar position (683 cm−1) to that of cobalt supported on pure magnesia (684 cm−1), thus evidencing a promotion of the interaction between cobalt and magnesium with increasing magnesium concentration at the cost of the interaction between cobalt and aluminium (Fig. 6 ). The redox properties of the samples were investigated by means of H2-TPR (Figs. 8 and 9 , Table 2 ). Note that the H2 uptake corresponding to the pure supports (Al2O3 and MgO) and MgO-modified alumina supports (Co/Mg-Al2O3) was negligible. For a better understanding of the influence of MgO deposition on the alumina support, the results corresponding to the catalysts supported on blank alumina and magnesia were firstly analysed. As for the samples supported on bare alumina (20Co/Al2O3 and 30Co/Al2O3), their TPR profiles evidenced two distinct H2 uptakes. The consumption observed at 250–500 °C was associated with the reduction of free Co3O4. In fact, two peaks could be ascertained in this temperature range at 300–325 and 400–425 °C in agreement with the well-known two-step reduction of Co3O4→CoO→Co [34]. The uptake located at markedly higher temperatures (above 550 °C) corresponded to the reduction of CoAl2O4, which was formed during the calcination step of the catalytic precursor [35]. The measured overall H2 uptakes were 18.6 mmol H2 gCo −1 (20Co/Al2O3) and 20.0 mmol H2 gCo −1 (30Co/Al2O3), significantly lower than the theoretical value for the full reduction of cobalt species as Co3O4 exclusively (22.6 mmol H2 gCo −1). At the same time, these values were larger than that corresponding to the exclusive presence of CoAl2O4 in the samples (17.0 mmol H2 gCo −1). Judging from these findings, it was reasonable to believe that a mixture of both Co3O4/CoAl2O4 was formed on the samples that presented an overall degree of reduction of 82 and 88%, respectively. As for the Co/MgO samples, a distinct H2 peak centred at 300 °C was noticed irrespective of the cobalt content, which was related to the reduction of free Co3O4. A substantial H2 consumption was also noticed in the 350–950 °C temperature range. This broad band was assigned to the reduction of a non-stoichiometric Mg-containing spinel phase and/or a CoO-MgO solid solution [36]. Similarly to the behaviour of the catalysts supported on bare alumina, it is worth pointing out the total H2 consumption of the Co/MgO samples was also considerably lower (13.1 mmol H2 gCo −1 for 20Co/MgO and 14.5 mmol H2 gCo −1 for 30Co/MgO) than the theoretical uptake. This implied that a notable fraction of Co species in these samples was present in the form of a highly stable, non-reducible solid solution with a reduction temperature above 950 °C. Consequently, an overall degree of reduction of 58 and 64%, respectively, was estimated. Judging from these results, it could be said that cobalt-magnesia interactions were comparatively much stronger than those created between cobalt species and alumina. The formation of CoO-MgO solid solution because of the diffusion of CoO into the MgO lattice was difficult to verify by XRD. No significant changes in the 2θ diffraction angles of the Co/MgO catalysts with respect to those of pure MgO were noted. Interestingly, an inspection of the 1000-1500 cm−1 region in the Raman spectra of these samples (20Co/MgO and 30Co/MgO) could reveal the presence of this solid solution. As shown in Fig. 10 , the spectrum of pure MgO displayed a band located at 1100 cm−1 that could be attributed to a two-phonon vibration induced by some disorder in the structure of magnesia [37,38]. When cobalt was deposited over the pure MgO, this disorder-induced band was still visible, along with additional bands centred at around 1250 and 1350 cm−1 that would imply an increase in the disorder of the structure of MgO due to insertion of cobalt ions and the subsequent formation of the solid solution [39]. Over the series of 20Co/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts, the total reducibility was enhanced with respect to the MgO-free sample (Table 2). In this way, a moderate increase by 5–10% was noticed. The largest promotion corresponded to the 20Co/12Mg-Al2O3 sample with an increase in the degree of reduction from 82% (20Co/Al2O3) to 91%. Furthermore, the onset of the reduction process of free Co3O4 significantly decreased by 35–50 °C. This shift was also more notable for the catalyst supported on 12Mg-Al2O3, as shown in Fig. 11 . Likewise a small shoulder at about 450–500 °C was noticed over the 20Co/12Mg-Al2O3 and 20Co/18Mg-Al2O3 samples. This evidenced that a minor fraction of deposited cobalt species strongly interacted with the promoter. On the other hand, it was found that the reduction band occurring at higher temperatures (above 550 °C), which was an evidence of the presence of CoAl2O4, was still noticed over the MgO-modified alumina catalysts, although its relative intensity was somewhat lower with respect to the catalysts supported over bare alumina. The same redox characteristics and trends were also recognised over the series of catalysts with 30%wt.Co (Fig. 9). This set of samples displayed a slightly higher specific H2 consumption (1–5%), which suggested that the overall reducibility was somewhat favoured with higher cobalt loadings (Table 2). Similarly, the reduction process started at lower temperatures with respect to the analogous catalyst supported on blank alumina (20–35 °C) (Fig. 11). In general, the redox behaviour of free Co3O4 present in the Co/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts tended to be more similar to that observed over the Co/MgO instead of the Co/Al2O3 counterpart, thereby evidencing a change in the nature of the cobalt-support interaction induced by the addition of magnesium to the alumina support in agreement with the results from XRD and Raman spectroscopy. An attempt was made to estimate the relative amount of each type of Co species present in the various catalysts by deconvoluting the experimental TPR profiles. The threshold temperature of 550 °C was taken as criterion to distinguish between easily reducible cobalt species (Region I) that would include free Co3O4 (200–450 °C) and cobalt-MgO species (450–550 °C) and hardly reducible cobalt species (Region II) in the form of cobalt aluminate (>550 °C) [40]. The results are summarised in Table 2. It was interesting to note that the amount of the first type of cobalt species increased when MgO was present on the support. This promotion was notable over the 20Co/Mg-Al2O3 (from 6.6 mmol H2 gCo −1 over 20Co/Al2O3 to 9.8 mmol H2 gCo −1 over 20Co/12Mg-Al2O3). On the contrary, it was less significant for the samples with 30%wt.Co (from 9.8 mmol H2 gCo −1 over 30Co/Al2O3 to 11–11.3 mmol H2 gCo −1 over 30Co/12Mg-Al2O3 and 30Co/18Mg-Al2O3). Simultaneously, increasing amounts of MgO led to a marked decrease in the fraction of hardly reducible CoAl2O4, which was about 8–12% lower for the Co/18Mg-Al2O3 samples. Hence, the coverage of alumina with MgO was shown to be efficient for partially inhibiting the strong interaction between Co3O4 and Al2O3 that could ultimately lead to the formation of cobalt aluminate. 3.3 Catalytic activity The catalytic efficiency was characterised by monitoring the rise in conversion as a function of temperature under given reaction conditions (300 ml CH4 g−1 h−1, about 60,000 h−1). Fig. 12 includes the corresponding conversion-temperature profiles of the investigated cobalt catalysts. The T50 value (temperature at which 50% conversion was attained) was used as an indicative of the relative reactivity of each sample (Table 3 ). It must be noticed that the oxidation of methane to exclusively CO2 was always observed in the whole temperature range. The reaction started to appreciably occur above 400 °C over the 20Co/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts and above 350 °C over the 30Co/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts. Accordingly, at 600 °C conversion values at around 65–80% and 80–95% were noted, respectively. The cobalt catalysts supported on modified alumina were more efficient than the corresponding alumina-supported counterparts regardless the Co content since the T50 values were lowered by 25–30 °C. Secondly, the samples with a 30%wt.Co were always more efficient irrespective of the support. For instance, T50 values were 525 and 550 °C over the 30Co/12Mg-Al2O3 and the 20Co/12Mg-Al2O3 catalysts, respectively. It seems reasonable to believe that the observed improvement in performance could be associated with the substantially enhanced redox properties of the catalysts due to MgO coverage of the alumina surface. Hence, the best results were found over the 30Co/12Mg-Al2O3 sample. The specific reaction rate of the cobalt catalysts was calculated at 450 °C (Table 3). This temperature was selected since it resulted in conversion values lower than 20% for all the samples. The estimated rates varied between 1.5–2.9 mmol h−1 gCo −1 over the 20Co/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts and between 2.7–3.5 mmol h−1 gCo −1 over the 30Co/Mg-Al2O3 samples. Note that the highest specific activity was found for the samples supported on 12 Mg/Al2O3. As can be seen, the promotion of catalytic activity when adding MgO was particularly marked in the former case since the reaction rate was doubled. Taking into consideration that the oxidation of methane over cobalt oxide catalysts involves the participation of highly active oxygen species [41], the observed increase in catalytic activity was proposed to be connected to the amount of easily reducible cobalt species the sample as expressed by the specific hydrogen uptake from Region I in the TPR profiles. In this sense, Fig. 13 shows that there was a reasonable good correlation between the specific reaction rate with the H2 consumption measured below 550 °C, that corresponded to active oxygen species involved in the reduction of free Co3O4 and unstable cobalt-MgO species. The apparent activation energy of the reaction over the investigated cobalt catalysts was evaluated by applying the integral method. A first pseudo-order for methane and a zero pseudo-order for oxygen were assumed on the basis of a simplified Mars–van Krevelen kinetics for this reaction studied with a high O2/CH4 molar ratio [42,43]. The results are listed in Table 3 while the corresponding plots for the linearized kinetic equation of the integral reactor are shown in Fig. 14 . The activation energies for the magnesium-free catalysts were relatively high, namely 104 and 90 kJ mol−1 over 20Co/Al2O3 and 30Co/Al2O3 samples, respectively, due to their relatively high content of inactive cobalt aluminate. However, with increasing magnesium loading for a given Co concentration, a decline in the apparent activation energy was evident. The lowest values were found for the Co/12Mg-Al2O3 catalysts (89 and 79 kJ mol−1 for 20Co/12Mg-Al2O3 and 30Co/12Mg-Al2O3, respectively). Over the catalysts with the highest Mg loading and the catalysts supported on pure MgO the apparent activation energy significantly increased up to 102–112 kJ mol−1. As illustrated in Fig. 15 , the observed trends of the dependence of the activation energy with Mg loading of the sample pointed out that the catalytic behaviour of Co3O4 crystallites in the two Co/12Mg-Al2O3 samples tended to show the highest similarity to that exhibited by the oxide particles present in a bulk Co3O4 catalyst, which gave an apparent activation energy of 74 kJ mol−1 [22,44]. This finding would be consistent with the lowest abundance of inactive, hardly reducible cobalt species such as CoAl2O4 and/or CoO-MgO solid solution on these two catalysts, and the concomitant largest population of highly active cobalt species mainly in the form of Co3O4. In this way, it could be established that the presence of CoAl2O4 would affect the performance of Co/Al2O3 and Co/7Mg-Al2O3 catalysts while the formation of a stable CoO-MgO solid solution would negatively impact the performance of Co/18Mg-Al2O3 and Co/MgO samples. Finally, a stability test over a prolonged period of time (150 h) was performed over the most active catalyst (30Co/12Mg-Al2O3) at 500 °C (Fig. 16 ). After a small drop in conversion from 36 to 30% during the first 25 h, the sample maintained a steady methane conversion for the remaining time on stream. This behaviour was consistent with an observed slight loss of surface area (about 10%, from 97 to 87 m2 g−1) that in turn was reflected in an alteration of the redox properties of the sample. Hence, although the overall H2 uptake did not vary significantly, the reduction temperatures shifted somewhat higher temperatures (around 20 °C). No enlargement of the crystallite size of the spinel phase was detected. 4 Conclusions The effect of MgO addition on the catalytic behaviour of alumina supported catalysts for the combustion of trace amounts of methane has been examined. Magnesia was deposited onto the alumina support prior to Co3O4 incorporation. From the textural point of view no marked effect was noticed after incorporating varying amounts of MgO (7–18%wt.Mg), due to the intrinsic properties of this promoter. When cobalt was deposited over these modified supports magnesium oxide acted as a barrier limiting the interaction between cobalt and alumina, consequently reducing the formation of inactive cobalt aluminate. In addition to that, the cobalt-magnesium interaction was found to be more beneficial to the redox properties of free Co3O4 than the cobalt-alumina interaction. Hence, the onset temperature for reduction was lowered and the overall hydrogen uptake of the catalysts significantly increased. As a result, the catalysts supported on the modified supports exhibited a higher activity than those supported on bare alumina. The highest reaction rate was achieved by the 30Co/Mg-Al2O3 catalyst, which was also deemed thermally stable for prolonged periods of operation. coredata.dc:description: The present work deals with the analysis of a series of cobalt catalysts (20 and 30%wt.Co) supported on alumina modified with MgO (7–18%wt.Mg with respect to the support) for the combustion of dilute methane. Both modified supports and the resulting cobalt catalysts were characterised by N2 physisorption, wavelength dispersive X-ray fluorescence, X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy and temperature-programmed reduction with hydrogen. A beneficial effect on catalytic activity was found with respect to the reference samples supported on blank alumina. As evidenced by the kinetic results in terms of specific reaction rate and apparent activation energy, this positive influence was related to a partial inhibition generation of less active CoAl2O4 due to MgO coverage of the support in favour of increasing the amount of easily reducible cobalt species, mainly in the form of Co3O4. The optimum magnesium loading was 12%wt. irrespective of the cobalt content, while the catalysts with 30%wt.Co were significantly more active than their counterparts with 20%wt.Co. Finally, a good catalytic stability with time on stream (150 h) was observed.
coredata.dc:title: On the beneficial effect of MgO promoter on the performance of Co3O4/Al2O3 catalysts for combustion of dilute methane
